content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: involves mathematics. i liked that part about it. i see that the user has also made adjustments. overall a solid puzzle

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: zadachata e 67

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Because everything is well defined

General
* The clash currently lacks any key programming elements such as lists, sets, dictionaries, string manipulation, loops, conditions…

Please add one or more programming elements so that the clash is more of a programming problem than a maths problem.

All sections
* Please format all the variables. Refer to the example here: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement

Input / Constraints
* Please use the same variable names as those in the stub generator, so "percent" instead of "%".

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback! I'll try my best to add more complexity to the clash.

EDIT:
I added an IF statement and a FOR loop hoping to increase the difficulty. I assume this is now adequate for a clash.

It's better now. Would you please further follow up as follows?

Goal
* Please delete "daily" to avoid misunderstanding.

* Please format "December" and "20%" as {{constants}}.

Input
* Please move "(e.g. 200 means the price is doubled)" to the Goal section.

Constraints
* Please reorder the constraints in the same order as input.

* For [[month]], please delete the brackets and change "using" to "starts with".

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario with slightly different inputs and outputs. Hence,
  • Please revise "High inflation" (Validator 3) to "No inflation" (both the name and the input should be changed).
  
  • Please revise "Exact Change" (Validator 4) to "Decimals" (both the name and the input should be changed). Ensure that the output doesn't end with ".00".

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback once more. The changes you mentioned have been applied, I also look forward to further advice if there's any of course.

Just one more thing:

Constraints
* Please format "month" as a [[variable]].

Thanks again!
